notes.title: What is the Performance Dashboard?
notes.body: The Performance Dashboard shows how government services are performing. Government services are required to publish 4 key performance indicators (KPIs) on the Performance Dashboard. These KPIs are cost per transaction, user satisfaction, digital take-up and completion rate.

notes.title: Who are the users of the Performance Dashboard?
notes.body: The Performance Dashboard’s users are anyone with an interest in how government services are performing, including the general public. Our vision is to drive the continuous improvement of government services, so our primary users are likely to include:
list: service managers — senior executives in government who can make decisions on service improvement
digital transformation champions — people who lead a digital shift in government agencies
digital transformation teams — government agency staff who have embarked on the transformation process

notes.title: User satisfaction
notes.body: User satisfaction measures the percentage of users who responded “satisfied” or “very satisfied” in our feedback survey. This figure is not yet statistically significant because of the low number of feedback responses from August 2016 onwards. In addition, we have no data for the months of May, June and July 2016 because no users provided feedback. We are determining the best way to encourage more feedback from our users.

notes.title: Cost per transaction
notes.body: Cost per transaction measures the costs of delivering a service for each time a user views the Performance Dashboard. It is calculated by determining the labour costs, including training, travel and other overheads, for the reporting period. (It does not include items such as product development and administration.) This figure is then divided by the number of sessions as recorded by Google Analytics for dashboard.gov.au. The result is an average cost per transaction for the reporting period. Over time, as more users view the dashboard, we expect this figure to come down. As we release self-service features, we anticipate this figure will come down.

notes.title: Digital take-up
notes.body: Digital take-up measures the percentage of services in public beta or live phases that have published a service dashboard to the Performance Dashboard. When a service enters public beta, it is required to publish its performance data on the dashboard. Digital take-up shows how many services have done this.

notes.title: Completion rate
notes.body: Completion rate measures the percentage of users who view Dashboard.gov.au and who then go on to view one or more service dashboards. For example, some users may only view the Dashboard.gov.au home page. Other users may then view a service dashboard. When users do this, we consider it a successful completion.

widgets.name: User Satisfaction
widgets.definition: Overall satisfaction score includes all ratings weighted from 100% for very satisfied to 0% for very dissatisfied

widgets.name: Completion Rate
widgets.definition: Percentage of transactions made using the digital service.

widgets.name: Number of users
widgets.definition: This shows the number of people visiting the Performance Dashboard each month.

widgets.name: Most-visited dashboards
widgets.description: The top 3 most-visited service dashboards are: 1. myGov 2. Australian Citizenship Booking Service 3. Hobby or Business Tool.

widgets.name: Types of service
widgets.description: This shows which the development phase the services that have published on the Performance Dashboard are in. It also shows services that are not going through a digital transformation and other types of projects such as information websites

widgets.name: Fact
widgets.description: The Performance Dashboard’s 3 primary goals are to increase the number of service dashboards it hosts, improve user engagement and to encourage automated publishing of data.

widgets.name: Dashboards viewed
widgets.definition: This shows the average number of service dashboards viewed each time a user visits the Performance Dashboard.

widgets.name: Average session length
widgets.definition: This shows the average length of time users spend visiting the Performance Dashboard.

widgets.name: Fact
widgets.description: We expect that rising user numbers, more dashboard views and longer session lengths will reveal higher levels of user engagement.

widgets.name: Fact
widgets.description: Our user satisfaction figures are not yet statistically significant because of the low feedback response so far. However, the average session length of more than 3 minutes shows that users are engaging well with the data provided.

widgets.name: Fact
widgets.description: The Performance Dashboard is being continuously improved to enable more than 100 high-volume services to publish their own service dashboards in the coming months. The ability to enter data automatically is part of this improvement.

widgets.name: How data is entered
widgets.definition: This shows how many services enter data manually to their dashboard and how many use automated procedures such as APIs.

widgets.name: How users find the dashboard
widgets.definition: This shows how users navigate to the Performance Dashboard. It show how many users type in the URL directly, find the dashboard on a search engine, click on a link in an article or another website, or come to it via social media.

widgets.name: New and returning users
widgets.definition: This shows the percentage of users visiting the Performance Dashboard for the first time compared to the percentage of users who have visited it before.

widgets.name: Devices used
widgets.definition: This shows which devices are used to view the Performance Dashboard.
